DataElement.preferredDefinition: Name to represent the histologic grade or differentiation of a lung tumor.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the lung tumor histologic classification or category.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has but two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border. SYN pulmo.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to histology.:Classification; the grouping of things into classes or categories.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Grade for a lung cancer histologic assessment.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that generally retain the appearance of normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally retain the appearance of normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells.
Describes tumor cells that generally have lost most of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost all of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread quickly and aggressively._The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost all of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread quickly and aggressively.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Indicates that a test was not performed.

Concepts.definition: Indicates that a test was not performed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The words or language units by which a thing is known.

Concepts.definition: The words or language units by which a thing is known.
